skill.name: metabolomics-workbench-database
skill.description: Access NIH Metabolomics Workbench via REST API (4,200+ studies). Query metabolites, RefMet nomenclature, MS/NMR data, m/z searches, study metadata, for metabolomics and biomarker discovery.
skill.summary: Access NIH Metabolomics Workbench via REST API (4,200+ studies). Query metabolites, RefMet nomenclat...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Only documentation and example API calls are present. No credential access, environment harvesting, or executable payloads are included. Network examples target the official Metabolomics Workbench domain.

content.user_title: Query metabolomics data via REST API
content.value_statement: Researchers need standardized metabolomics data from authoritative sources. This skill provides precise REST API guidance for querying 4,200+ studies, metabolite structures, and mass spectrometry data from NIH Metabolomics Workbench.
actual_capabilities: Query compound data by PubChem CID, KEGG ID, HMDB ID, or InChI Key
Search 4,200+ metabolomics studies by metabolite, disease, or experimental parameters
Standardize metabolite names using RefMet hierarchical classification
Perform m/z searches with customizable adducts and mass tolerance
Filter studies by analytical method, species, sample source, and disease
Retrieve gene and protein data associated with metabolic pathways
limitations: Provides API guidance only - no direct data analysis or interpretation
Cannot access private studies without proper authentication
Dependent on Metabolomics Workbench API availability and performance
Large dataset queries may require pagination and caching strategies

use_cases.title: Find disease-specific studies
use_cases.description: Locate metabolomics studies for specific diseases and sample types using MetStat filters to identify relevant datasets for analysis.

use_cases.title: Standardize metabolite nomenclature
use_cases.description: Map common metabolite names to standardized RefMet names and retrieve hierarchical classifications for consistent data integration.

use_cases.title: Identify compounds from MS data
use_cases.description: Search for candidate compounds using m/z values with appropriate ion adducts and mass tolerance settings.

prompt_templates.title: List public studies
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to list all publicly available metabolomics studies and retrieve the summary for study ST000001.

prompt_templates.title: Standardize metabolite name
prompt_templates.prompt: Find the RefMet standardized name for 'citric acid' and show me the API request URL.

prompt_templates.title: m/z compound identification
prompt_templates.prompt: Search the Metabolomics Workbench database for compounds with m/z 180.06 using M+H adduct and 0.5 Da tolerance.

prompt_templates.title: Filter studies by parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a MetStat query to find human plasma diabetes studies analyzed by LC-MS in positive mode with HILIC chromatography.

output_examples.input: Find studies containing glucose and show how to get detailed data
output: First, standardize the metabolite name: GET /refmet/match/glucose/name/json
Select a study ID and retrieve data: GET /study/study_id/ST000001/data/json

best_practices: Always standardize metabolite names with RefMet before searching studies to ensure consistent results
Use appropriate mass tolerance values (0.5 Da for low-res, 0.01 Da for high-res MS) in m/z searches
Cache frequently accessed reference data like RefMet classifications to minimize API calls
anti_patterns: Searching studies with non-standardized metabolite names may return incomplete results
Using overly broad MetStat queries without filters can return excessive data
Ignoring output format specifications may cause parsing issues in automated workflows

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill provides REST API guidance that works across all platforms including Claude, Codex, and Claude Code.

faq.question: What are the API usage limits?
faq.answer: No strict limits are published, but implement reasonable delays between bulk requests and cache reference data.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into my analysis pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, use the documented REST endpoints from Python, R, or any scripting language to automate data retrieval.

faq.question: Does this skill access my local data or files?
faq.answer: No, it only documents public API endpoints and does not read or write any local files or data.

faq.question: How do I handle API errors or empty results?
faq.answer: Check HTTP status codes, validate endpoint paths, ensure proper URL encoding, and handle empty JSON arrays gracefully.

faq.question: How does this compare to downloading the entire database?
faq.answer: API access provides on-demand data without local storage overhead, though bulk downloads may be better for offline analysis.
